column1: meet george;We need your help. My name is George
column3: you're one of many thousands who have seen this message. Those capable of helping us have either turned away or have simply failed. Nine years ago
column4: I was diagnosed with a disease causing fast-spreading neural deterioration. At first
column5: it was thought to be Alzheimers or other similar neurodegenerative disease
column6: however after agreeing to have my brain biopsied
column7: there was no presence of the amyloid-β nor tau plaques frequently associated with the disease. In layman's terms
column8: my brain was falling apart and nobody could tell me why... If you can help me
column9: I've spread my story throughout your world.;The piece of the puzzle is hidden under your girlfriend's favorite part of your backyard. Hurry.

column1: the clue you seek is hidden in a game you've yet to beat;After seeing many specialists
column2: I was introduced to an experimental trial group two years after discovering I was dying. Dr. Hand led the trials
column3: and he first introduced me to Margret. She was a woman of sixty-some-odd years
column4: donning a head of jet-black hair with only a handful of grey hairs which she complained about incessantly. She had been a patient of Hand's for about ten years
column5: so I finally had hope after being shuffled around from doctor to doctor
column7: I was pleading for something that simply didn't exist. After about a year
column8: death would have been preferable to the suffering brought on by uncertainty. The clock ticked erratically as I began to lose my mind.;This next one should be easy for you. Earlier this summer
column9: you recieved a few short novels from your girlfriend.One of them holds the key. For security's sake
column10: I've created a new measure of uniqueness. (number of lonely words) * (number of duplicate words). Type up the letters and write something to do this for you. Have you met python + regex yet? (hint. I'm->im; all content is fair game)

column4: my insanity picked up and left. I could look at my watch once more without my heart skipping one to five beats. Reality began to seep back into my life
column5: concentrating the world I had made up in the darkest corners of my brain. Margret recalled having a similar experience when became the first of the trial subjects. Suddenly
column6: I found myself easing into my newfound life.;What do this csv (https://www.dropbox.com/s/3hzzhv84ly8n0lo/haHA.csv?dl=0) and sharing have in common? Stay tuned to the words and remember that we've had a lot of firsts this year. Remember that all of these clues are case-sensitive.

column2: I was introduced to the rest of the trial group. Dwayne and Jeffrey quickly became my two closest friends in the group of fifteen. Those two couldn't be much different from one another. They grew up down the street from one another. Dwayne came from a well-off family
column3: but struggled to find himself. Jeffrey's room was the basement of his house
column4: and he and Dwayne used to play video games for hours together there. Even single player games they didn't mind sharing
column5: because they were happy to have one another's company. The outcome of the game was never the objective. Jeffrey was the first of the two in the trial group and was followed by Dwayne just under a year later. Sam
column9: and PJ comprised the remainder of the group.;bomb. sure stop pun Dana lux max hew aptly hue. if mae prob ak lux. if but a up lat. cum opt. coo let. ass! oaf!!

column1: bomb. sure stop pun Dana lux max hew aptly hue. if mae prob ak lux. if but a up lat. cum opt. coo let. ass! oaf!!;In one of my early sessions with the doctor
column2: I mustered up the courage to ask him about how he got involved in doing research for it. He responded saying that he refused to give a name to the disease – it wasn't worthy of one. He believed in nothing more than his abilities
column3: but that began to change as he watched his son wither away from something similar over twenty years ago. An early onset neurodegenerative disease would not have made sense for his six year old son Thomas.Though he never verbalized it
column4: everybody knows Hand blames himself daily for the inevitable loss of his son. Even his smile is never quite full
column5: and his eyes remain matte no matter how excited he claims to be. He would always mumble to himself
column7: "If you're still with me..." and then he trails off.;

column1: didsomeonesaymusic;PJ once explained to me that Dr. Hand used to tell him when life took life as its fuel
column2: life was onto something. The doctor believed in no god more powerful than himself
column3: yet he seemed to disagree that evolution was entirely randomized. Somehow
column4: life was being propagated in many forms in an internal battle against the second law of thermodynamics. How is it that on Earth
column5: life gets more orderly while entropy is always increasing? It never made sense to him
column6: so he's dedicated his life to figuring out what was so important that his son had to die for it.;check back later for your next clue
